G.L. c. 212, \u00a7 3.proposition: The amount in controversy exceeds $50,000, exclusive of interest and costs, placing this matter within the jurisdiction of the Superior Court pursuant to G.L. c. 212, § 3.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a7\u00a7 1, 2.proposition: Venue is proper in Middlesex County under G.L. c. 223, §§ 1, 2, and applicable Massachusetts law because the cause of action arose from an incident that occurred in Lowell, Massachusetts, within Middlesex County, at Defendant’s Store located at 110 Market Street, Lowell, MA 01852.

Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693, 707 (1.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, a store owner or occupier of land owes a duty to lawful visitors and business invitees to exercise reasonable care to keep the premises in a reasonably safe condition and to protect them against foreseeable risks of harm.
Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693, 707 (1.support_reasoning: Mounsey v. Ellard is the leading Massachusetts case abolishing the common‑law distinction between licensees and invitees and imposing on occupiers of land a general duty of reasonable care to all lawful visitors. While the provided excerpt is a concurrence focused on trespassers and does not itself restate the duty, the majority opinion at 363 Mass. 693, 707 clearly holds that occupiers must exercise reasonable care to keep premises reasonably safe for lawful visitors, including business invitees. Thus, the case supports the proposition, though the specific quoted passage does not describe the duty directly.
Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693, 707 (1.relevant_excerpt: [From the majority opinion at 363 Mass. 693, 707:] “We hold that the common law distinctions between invitees and licensees are no longer to be recognized in this Commonwealth. The proper test of the landowner’s liability is whether in the management of his property he has acted as a reasonable man in view of the probability of injury to others. Thus, an occupier of land owes to all lawful visitors a duty of reasonable care under all of the circumstances.”

Davis v. Westwood Group, 420 Mass. 739,.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, a store owner or occupier of land owes a duty to lawful visitors and business invitees to exercise reasonable care to keep the premises in a reasonably safe condition and to protect them against foreseeable risks of harm.
Davis v. Westwood Group, 420 Mass. 739,.support_reasoning: The opinion squarely states the Massachusetts common-law duty of an owner or possessor of land to lawful visitors: a duty of reasonable care, including maintaining the premises in reasonably safe condition and warning of unreasonable dangers. Although the case ultimately holds there is no duty to alter an adjacent state highway, its articulation of the baseline premises-liability duty to lawful visitors and invitees matches the proposition. The limitation concerns extension to public highways, not the core duty described in the proposition.
Davis v. Westwood Group, 420 Mass. 739,.relevant_excerpt: “It is well established that an owner or possessor of land owes a common law duty of reasonable care to all lawful visitors. Sullivan v. Brookline, 416 Mass. 825, 827 (1994), citing Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693, 707 (1973). This duty includes an obligation to maintain the premises in reasonably safe condition and to warn visitors of any unreasonable dangers of which the landowner is aware or reasonably should be aware.”

Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc.raw_text: Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc., 448 Mass. 780, 782–84 (2007)
Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc.proposition: This duty includes the obligation to maintain aisles, shelving, and merchandise displays in a reasonably safe condition; to use reasonable care in stocking and securing merchandise; to conduct reasonable inspections; and to either remedy or warn of unreasonable risks of harm of which the defendant knows or should know.
Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc.case_name: Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc.
Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc.support_reasoning: The opinion squarely addresses a store owner’s duty in premises liability and states that a store must maintain its property in a reasonably safe condition and take steps a reasonably prudent person would take to prevent accidents from foreseeable hazards. While the case is focused on notice and the mode-of-operation doctrine rather than listing specific duties like stocking, securing merchandise, or conducting inspections, the described duty to maintain premises in a reasonably safe condition and to take reasonable precautions against foreseeable risks is consistent with, and broadly encompasses, those obligations. The case therefore provides general doctrinal support, though not in the same detailed breakdown used in the proposition.
Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc.relevant_excerpt: “Historically, Massachusetts has also followed the traditional approach governing premises liability. A store owner has been required to maintain its property ‘in a reasonably safe condition in view of all the circumstances, including the likelihood of injury to others, the seriousness of the injury, and the burden of avoiding the risk.’… [T]he trier of fact must determine whether the owner could reasonably foresee or anticipate that a foreseeable risk stemming from the owner’s mode of operation could occur and whether the owner exercised reasonable care in maintaining the premise in a safe condition commensurate with these foreseeable risks.”

Deagle v. Great Atl. & Pac. Tea Co., 343.raw_text: Deagle v. Great Atl. & Pac. Tea Co., 343 Mass. 263, 264–65 (1961)
Deagle v. Great Atl. & Pac. Tea Co., 343.proposition: This duty includes the obligation to maintain aisles, shelving, and merchandise displays in a reasonably safe condition; to use reasonable care in stocking and securing merchandise; to conduct reasonable inspections; and to either remedy or warn of unreasonable risks of harm of which the defendant knows or should know.
Deagle v. Great Atl. & Pac. Tea Co., 343.case_name: Deagle v. Great Atlantic & Pacific Tea Co.
Deagle v. Great Atl. & Pac. Tea Co., 343.support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly states the storeowner’s duty to keep premises reasonably safe for customers and explains that when a dangerous condition arises, the owner must have a reasonable opportunity to learn of it and then either remedy it or warn customers. The court focuses on constructive notice, inspection opportunity, and the need to remove or warn of dangerous conditions, which aligns with the proposition about maintaining aisles and displays in a reasonably safe condition, using reasonable care, and either remedying or warning of known or knowable risks.
Deagle v. Great Atl. & Pac. Tea Co., 343.relevant_excerpt: “The defendant owed to customers a duty to keep the premises reasonably safe for their use. He, however, is not an insurer of safety. Where, without action for which he is responsible, a dangerous condition arises, the law allows him reasonable opportunity to become informed of the danger and to take measures to remedy it. He is not liable, in such a case, unless he is negligent in failing to inform himself and to take appropriate action… In this state of the case it was incumbent upon the plaintiff to show that the oil had been on the floor for such a length of time that the defendant’s employees, in the exercise of reasonable care, should have been aware of its presence and taken steps to remove it or to warn the customers.”

Mullins v. Pine Manor Coll., 389 Mass. 4.raw_text: Mullins v. Pine Manor Coll., 389 Mass. 47, 54–55 (1983)
Mullins v. Pine Manor Coll., 389 Mass. 4.proposition: The risk that heavy boxes stacked high on retail shelving could fall and strike a customer below if the shelf were jostled or bumped by a shopping cart was reasonably foreseeable to a prudent store operator in Defendant’s position.
Mullins v. Pine Manor Coll., 389 Mass. 4.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns a college’s duty to protect a student from criminal assault and the foreseeability of rape in relation to campus security measures. It does not involve retail premises, stacked merchandise, shelves, or falling objects. The foreseeability analysis here is about criminal acts and security (gates, guards, locked buildings), not about the physical risk of boxes falling from shelving, so it provides no authority for the specific retail-operations proposition stated.
Mullins v. Pine Manor Coll., 389 Mass. 4.relevant_excerpt: "The plaintiff had the burden of proving 'that the defendant[ ] took a risk with respect to the plaintiff’s safety that a person of ordinary prudence would not have taken, and that the plaintiff suffered a resulting injury that was within the foreseeable risk.' Cimino v. Milford Keg, Inc., 385 Mass. 323, 330 (1982). ... The foreseeable risk of an inadequately secured gate is that an intruder might enter the premises for mischievous purposes."

Thurlow v. Crossman, 336 Mass. 248, 251.proposition: This knowledge is imputed to Defendant through its employees charged with stocking and inspecting the premises.
Thurlow v. Crossman, 336 Mass. 248, 251.support_reasoning: The opinion deals with whether a state coastal warden was a trespasser when entering private property in the performance of his official duties. It does not address imputation of knowledge from employees to a defendant entity, nor stocking or inspecting premises. The cited case is therefore not authority for the proposition that knowledge is imputed to a defendant through its employees charged with stocking and inspecting the premises.
Thurlow v. Crossman, 336 Mass. 248, 251.relevant_excerpt: “A police officer who enters upon private premises in good faith in the performance of his official duty to protect life and property and to preserve the peace is not a trespasser. Parker v. Barnard, 135 Mass. 116, 117. Wynn v. Sullivan, 294 Mass. 562, 564.”

Oliveri v. Mass. Bay Transp. Auth., 363.raw_text: Oliveri v. Mass. Bay Transp. Auth., 363 Mass. 165, 167–68 (1973)
Oliveri v. Mass. Bay Transp. Auth., 363.proposition: Defendant had actual or constructive notice of the hazardous condition caused by its stocking practices, because Defendant created the condition itself by stacking the heavy boxes as described, and because such a method of display inherently involved a continuing risk of falling merchandise.
Oliveri v. Mass. Bay Transp. Auth., 363.case_name: Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transportation Authority
Oliveri v. Mass. Bay Transp. Auth., 363.support_reasoning: The proposition concerns constructive notice where the defendant itself creates a hazardous condition through its stocking/display practices and the inherently risky method of display. Oliveri, however, is a subway-stair foreign-substance case focused on whether circumstantial evidence showed the substance had been present long enough to impute notice; there is no discussion of the defendant creating the condition through stocking or display practices. The case articulates general premises-liability and notice principles but does not support the specific proposition about hazards created by a defendant’s own stacking method.
Oliveri v. Mass. Bay Transp. Auth., 363.relevant_excerpt: “Where a foreign substance on a floor or stairway causes the business visitor to fall and sustain injuries, he may prove the negligence of the defendant by proof that the defendant or his servant caused the substance to be there, or he may show that the defendant or his servants had actual knowledge of the existence of the foreign substance… In the more usual case, however, the plaintiff attempts to establish the defendant’s negligence by showing that the foreign substance was present… for such a length of time that the defendant should have known about it.”

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 60F.proposition: As a direct and proximate result of Defendant’s negligence, Plaintiff incurred and continues to incur reasonable and necessary medical expenses in an amount of approximately $1,800.00 to date, and may incur additional expenses in the future.

Feltch v. Gen. Rental Co., 383 Mass. 603.raw_text: Feltch v. Gen. Rental Co., 383 Mass. 603, 611 (1981)
Feltch v. Gen. Rental Co., 383 Mass. 603.proposition:
As a direct and foreseeable result of Defendant’s negligence, Plaintiff sustained bodily injuries, including but not limited to:

    a. Mild concussion, with associated dizziness, headaches, and cognitive symptoms; and  
    b. Shoulder strain, with associated pain, limited range of motion, and functional limitation.
Feltch v. Gen. Rental Co., 383 Mass. 603.support_reasoning: The opinion describes the plaintiff’s actual injuries (fractured hip, back injuries, depression, irritability, sexual impotence) but does not address or mention a mild concussion, dizziness, headaches, cognitive symptoms, or a shoulder strain. The case is about comparative negligence, loss of consortium, and vicarious liability of a vehicle owner, not about the specific types of bodily injuries listed in the proposition. Therefore, it does not provide authority that defendant’s negligence caused the particular injuries identified in the claimed proposition.
Feltch v. Gen. Rental Co., 383 Mass. 603.relevant_excerpt: “The plaintiff Donald Feltch was injured when the defendant Robert Randall drove a truck into an electric cable that Feltch and a two-man crew were installing. As a result Feltch suffered a fractured hip and back injuries, was hospitalized for several weeks, and was disabled for many months. He also became depressed, irritable with his wife, and sexually impotent.”

Payton v. Abbott Labs, 386 Mass. 540, 55.proposition: As a direct and proximate result of Defendant’s negligence, Plaintiff has suffered loss of enjoyment of life, emotional distress, inconvenience, and other non-economic damages compensable under Massachusetts negligence law.
Payton v. Abbott Labs, 386 Mass. 540, 55.support_reasoning: The proposition claims Massachusetts negligence law allows recovery for non‑economic damages like loss of enjoyment of life and emotional distress as a proximate result of negligence. Payton, in the cited pages, holds the opposite for this context: it expressly rejects a negligence claim for emotional distress absent physical harm and sets strict requirements (including objective physical symptomatology) for negligent infliction of emotional distress. The decision does not affirm general recoverability of emotional distress or other non‑economic harms from negligence without those limitations, so it does not support the broad proposition cited.
Payton v. Abbott Labs, 386 Mass. 540, 55.relevant_excerpt: “We conclude that when recovery is sought for negligent, rather than intentional or reckless, infliction of emotional distress, evidence must be introduced that the plaintiff has suffered physical harm… We therefore conclude… that in order for any of these plaintiffs to recover for negligently inflicted emotional distress, she must allege and prove she suffered physical harm… the physical harm must be manifested by objective symptomatology and substantiated by expert medical testimony… In summary, we hold that a plaintiff in order to recover for negligently inflicted emotional distress must prove… (4) physical harm manifested by objective symptomatology…” (386 Mass. at 555–57).

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 85.proposition: Plaintiff’s own conduct was at all times reasonable and did not constitute negligence, or, in the alternative, any negligence on Plaintiff’s part was less than the negligence of Defendant and does not bar recovery but, at most, would proportionally reduce damages under Massachusetts’ comparative negligence statute, G.L. c. 231, § 85.

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 60H.proposition: Under G.L. c. 231, § 60H, Plaintiff is entitled to recover the full measure of his tort damages, including past and future medical expenses, lost wages and earning capacity, and pain and suffering, subject to the fact-finder’s determination.

MacCuish v. Volkswagenwerk A.G., 22 Mass.raw_text: MacCuish v. Volkswagenwerk A.G., 22 Mass. App. Ct. 380, 397–98 (1986)
MacCuish v. Volkswagenwerk A.G., 22 Mass.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, a plaintiff in a negligence action is entitled to recover fair and reasonable compensation for all harms proximately caused by defendant’s breach of duty, including both economic and non-economic damages.
MacCuish v. Volkswagenwerk A.G., 22 Mass.support_reasoning: The opinion is a wrongful death/products liability case and does not state the general negligence damages principle described in the proposition. Its discussion of damages is confined to interpreting the Massachusetts wrongful death statute, focusing on what components (e.g., loss of society vs. grief, anguish, and bereavement) are recoverable by statutory beneficiaries, not on a general common-law negligence rule about economic and non-economic damages for all harms proximately caused. Thus, it is not proper authority for the broader negligence damages proposition cited.
MacCuish v. Volkswagenwerk A.G., 22 Mass.relevant_excerpt: “The wrongful death statute, G. L. c. 229, § 2… provides that a person who ‘[i] by his negligence causes the death of a person… or [v] is responsible for a breach of warranty… which results in injury to a person that causes death, shall be liable in damages in the amount of: (1) the fair monetary value of the decedent to the persons entitled to receive the damages recovered… including but not limited to compensation for the loss of the reasonably expected net income, services, protection, care, assistance, society, companionship, comfort, guidance, counsel, and advice of the decedent….’”

doCanto v. Ametek, Inc., 367 Mass. 776,.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, a plaintiff in a negligence action is entitled to recover fair and reasonable compensation for all harms proximately caused by defendant’s breach of duty, including both economic and non-economic damages.
doCanto v. Ametek, Inc., 367 Mass. 776,.support_reasoning: The opinion in doCanto deals with product design negligence, evidentiary issues, duty to warn, consortium, and whether a personal injury verdict was excessive. Although the court lists the elements of damages considered (lost earning capacity, pain and suffering, disfigurement, future medical devices, etc.), it does so only in the context of reviewing excessiveness, not to articulate a general rule of Massachusetts law on the scope of recoverable negligence damages. The case therefore does not purport to state or analyze the broad proposition that a plaintiff is entitled to fair and reasonable compensation for all harms proximately caused, including both economic and non-economic damages; it simply applies those concepts implicitly in reviewing a verdict.
doCanto v. Ametek, Inc., 367 Mass. 776,.relevant_excerpt: “In concluding that the judge committed no error of law, we consider Ezila’s age (twenty-nine) and weekly earnings ($140) at the time of the accident; the loss of ninety-five per cent of the function of her right hand (her dominant hand); her inability to perform many household tasks or to obtain employment; her pain and suffering… her disfigurement… her future need for artificial hands; and her continuing discomfort and embarrassment. Although many of these elements of damage are incapable of precise, monetary measurement, the trial judge… is in a far better position than we to determine the reasonableness of the jury’s award.”}

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 6B.proposition: Plaintiff seeks an amount of damages to be determined by the trier of fact, in an amount sufficient to fully and fairly compensate him for all harms suffered and to be suffered as a result of Defendant’s negligence, plus statutory interest and costs as permitted by Massachusetts law, including G.L. c. 231, § 6B (prejudgment interest in tort actions).

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 60C.proposition: Pursuant to Article 15 of the Massachusetts Declaration of Rights and G.L. c. 231, § 60C, Plaintiff hereby demands a trial by jury on all issues so triable.
